class_d_01_language_01:
My dear students! How ARE you all today?
Feeling good, I hope?[VAR 0114(002C)]
class_d_01_language_02: Je m’appelle Salvatore. My name is Salvatore![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_03:
Merci beaucoup! That is, thank you very much for
your attention here in my class![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_04:
I’m so heureux—or happy—for this chance to
re-experience my younger days with you all![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_05:
Do you know what “Salvatore” means? It means
“savior”! So just imagine I’m here to SAVE you\r
from spooooky new languages. Haha! Funny, no?[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_06:
That’s right! My classes will teach you about
various languages from different regions.[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_07:
You may say “Good morning!” or “Hello!” as a
greeting, but people from elsewhere may say\r
“Bonjour!” or “Salut!”[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_08:
I’ve heard there’s even a popular streamer out
there who smashes several languages together\r
and says “’Ello, ’ello, hola! Ciao and bonjour!”[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_09:
There are so many regions out there in our world,
and each can have their own unique languages![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_10:
Gracias, merci, xièxie, arigato, danke—these all
have the same meaning! Can you guess what it is?[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_answer_01:
Oh! [VAR TRNAME(0000)], was it?\c
That’s not quite right, but your willingness to
speak up will serve you well in language learning![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_answer_02:
Waouh! [VAR TRNAME(0000)], was it?\c
Brav[VAR GENDBR(00FF,0101)]oa! That’s correct! And speaking up is
important in language learning, too![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_answer_03:
Oh! [VAR TRNAME(0000)], was it?\c
That’s not quite right, but your willingness to
speak up will serve you well in language learning![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_11:
Gracias, merci, xièxie—these words all mean
“thank you.” I guess some of you probably knew\r
at least one of those![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_12:
Despite meaning the same thing, their lengths
and sounds are all different! Isn’t that interesting?[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_13:
And now, apropos of nothing, let me give you
all one of my wise words of advice![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_14:
When you travel abroad, you should try to speak
the local language as much as you can—even if\r
you can’t speak it very well![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_15:
I’m sure your willingness to try will make the
people you meet très heureux—very happy![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_16:
Honestly, from my experience, just being able to
say “hello,” “delicious,” and “thank you” in the\r
local language will get you pretty far.[VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_17:
For everything else, just pretend you’re Mr. Mime
and gesture away![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_18:
Oh! There’s that pesky bell. I guess that’s all the
time we have for today![VAR 0114(0026)]
class_d_01_language_19:
Well, adios! Mata ne! À la prochaine! See you
later, everyone![VAR 0114(0026)]
